Problem:
Consider a linear system governed by the differential equation \\(\\dot{x} = Mx\\), where M is a diagonalizable matrix. We introduce an operator transformation \\( F(x) = Ax \\), where A is another matrix, and analyze its effect on the system over a period of time t.

If the transformation \\( F(x) \\) is applied to an initial state \\( x_0 \\) at time t = 0 and the system is then allowed to evolve according to \\(\\dot{x} = Mx\\) without any further intervention, will the state \\( x(t) \\) at time t = T be the same as if \\( x_0 \\) was directly evolved under \\(\\dot{x} = Mx\\)?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\( F(x) = Ax \\) changes the initial conditions of the system by transforming \\( x_0 \\) into \\( Ax_0 \\). The evolution from \\( Ax_0 \\) under \\(\\dot{x} = Mx\\) generally differs from that of \\( x_0 \\) unless A commutes with the exponential of M, that is, unless \\( AM = MA \\).
